editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

AND Their Re≈øolution to adhere thereunto, and to pre≈øerve and maintain their ancient Government, by a mixt Monarchy of KING, LORDS, and COMMONS, and their further proceedings thereupon, in relation to their young King, and the Parliament of ENGLAND.

ALSO, A Declaration to the Citizens of London, concerning twenty thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot to be rai≈øed for the Prince, under the command of Generall Hatzfield, with the advice and Propo≈øals thereupon.
AND The King of Denmark's ≈øending forth a new Fleet to fall vpon the Engli≈øh Ships.
Imprinted at London, for R. William≈øon, 1649.

div.head: THE DECLARATION Of the Kingdom of SCOTLAND FOR Religion, Crown, and Covenant; and their Re≈øolution touching the Parliament of England; their preparations to fight for Charles the ≈øecond, and 8000 Hor≈øe and 12000 Foot rai≈øing in Holland.
div.p:
THe Parliament of Scotland begins to di≈øplay the banner of great Politicians, and have taken an Oath of Secre≈øie not to impart or di≈øclo≈øe the re≈øults of their debates til all things come to maturity and ripene≈ø≈øe: all their con≈øultations tends to the purging of the Army, adhering to their Covenant, and maintaining their Government by a mixt Monarchy of King, Lords, and Commons; and in order thereunto,
the major part have entred into prote≈øt, and declared, in the name of all the Commons of that Kingdom, That they will (to the utmo≈øt of their power) endeavour the pre≈øervation of the peace and tranquility thereof, again≈øt all oppo≈øition or power what≈øoever, and that they will likewi≈øe endeavour the true e≈øtabli≈øhing of a firm and un≈øpotted Monarchy (which can hardly be) according to the ancient Lawes Liberties and Cu≈øtome of that Kingdom, and doth further remon≈øtrate exceeding high language again≈øt the Parliament of England, in reference to the late Kings execution, & their pre≈øent tran≈øactions between Parliament and Army: But their young Kings An≈øwer ≈øeeming un≈øatisfactory to the de≈øires of the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Kirk, cau≈øeth them rather to pray for his Conver≈øion; then advi≈øe his Conformity.

However, the vulgar ≈øort of people ≈øeem to re≈øcent his conde≈øcen≈øions, and ≈øay, that unle≈ø≈øe their plants receive moi≈øture from the ≈øap of the Cedar, the bark and pith of the poor Shrub will fade and decay.

Hence it is, that tyrannicall Oppre≈ø≈øors have received an allarum throughout all Ages, with the de≈øperate Careers of a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed multitude, who no ≈øooner enter by ≈øtorme, but they make their enemies (though never ≈øo great) drink the dregs of their cup of fury, and not only ≈øo, but leaves them and their I≈ø≈øue, odious to all po≈øterity.

But its hoped that tho≈øe who keep their Trophies of Victoria by love, will challenge a high applau≈øe of Chri≈øtianity and Souldiery, and attempt de≈øperate adventures for the bringing of their oppre≈ø≈øors to a ≈øpeedy ruine; notwith≈øtanding all their forraign machaviliani≈øm, to a new involving; It being apparent that their pre≈øent actings beyond the Seas, tends to the univer≈øall de≈øtruction of the well-affected party throughout the three Nations; the which, that it may appear
more vi≈øible to your ≈øtately Fabrick and renowned Metropolis, I ≈øhall here repre≈øent unto the Ornaments and Inhabitants thereof, a perfect Demon≈øtration and Declaration of the proceedings of the King of Scots and his Adherents, in reference to an engagement again≈øt them; to the end they may receive a timely allarum, for a ananimous a≈ø≈øociation, with tho≈øe renowned Tru≈øtees, who have ≈øo deerly purcha≈øed their liberties; the ≈øum and ab≈øtract whereof I ≈øhall here in≈øert as followeth, viz.

The King of Scots hath ≈øent ≈øeverall Emba≈ø≈øies to forraign Princes and Potentates; to wit, the mo≈øt high and mighty Imperiali≈øt, the Emperour of Germany, Philip King of Spain, Lewis King of France, and the mo≈øt pious and vertuous Prince≈ø≈øe the Queen of Swethland, earne≈øtly imploring timely ayd and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance for his re≈øtauration; and we hear that great preparations are (there) making ≈øuitable to his De≈øires, and that upon the Confines of High Germany ≈øeverall Regiments of Hor≈øe and Foot are rai≈øing, which are to be di≈øtinctly divided into four Brigades, each Brigade to con≈øi≈øt of 4000 Hor≈øe, and 6000 Foot, to be commanded by Generall Hatzfield, who hath Commi≈ø≈øion proffered from the King of Scots, for the leading and conducting of them according as his titular Maje≈øty and his Councell ≈øhall determine of. (This Generall Hatzfield hath a point of great policy if he can rai≈øe ≈øomthing out of nothing; for although there be ≈øo many de≈øigned, yet there are not a quarter ≈øo many (as yet) levied.

We hear that the King of Denmark hath ≈øent an additionall Fleet to the Zund, to intercept and fall upon the Engli≈øh ≈øhips at their return from the Ea≈øt Country; and for certain it is, that both the Scots and others have them in a univer≈øall hatred.

THe Marq. of Ormond with 13000 Hor≈øe and Foot is ≈øate down before the City of Dublin, with a re≈øolution to storm, if not ≈øuddenly ≈øurrendred upon ≈øummons; but renowned Col. Jones hath taken a re≈øolution to fight it out to the last man, and hath already made a gallant attempt and inroad vpon his Outquartes with 2000 Hor≈øe and Foot; and after a ≈øharp conflict Col. Jones made an honourable retreat into the City with the lo≈øse of 7 or 8, be≈øides ≈øome ≈øew wounded; but the Lord Inchiquins Brigade of hor≈øe being gallantly mounted, took vpon them great re≈øolution, and embraced the pur≈øuit within a quarter of a mile of the Gates, where we had a ≈øecond engagement, which continued very dubious for the ≈øpace of half an hour, till at last a con≈øiderable party of the Sea-men came in to our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, who by their lining of the hedges, did ≈øo gall the Enemy, that they were forced to retreat, leaving above 30 men dead vpon the place; in which fight we took Captain Smith, Cornet John≈øon, and about ten more pri≈øoners, with the lo≈øse of five men.

Since which time, they have made another attempt vpon our Out-guards, and vpon the neer approoch of their forlorn hope con≈øi≈øting of about 60 hor≈øe, 30 of ours an≈øwered their charge, and ≈øhot Lieut. Col. Dungans hor≈øe vnder him, took him pri≈øoner, and Major Dungan his brother was mortally wounded, our men brought off 7 of their hor≈øe, and (ble≈øsed be God) but one man wounded, none ≈ølain.

They are incamped within a mile and a half of the City, where they expect the coming vp of the Earl of Clanrickard, Lord Taff, and the Lord Dillon, with their forces, for a ≈øudden conjunction; and then to make a ≈øharp ≈øtorm.

Their Tents are pitcht on this ≈øide Fingles, their hor≈øe and foot lye all in our ≈øight; Col. Jones is labouring hard to fortifie against them, hath given Orders for the pulling down all the Outhou≈øes that may advantage their de≈øign, and hath ≈øet forth Proclamation for all the Iri≈øh Papists, and other di≈øaffected
Citizens, to depart the City within 12 hours after the publi≈øhing thereof; by who≈øe unwearied pains and vigilancy, we are in ≈øome rea≈øonable po≈ø≈øibility of the more ≈øafety thereby, & have hard duty to attend the Line dayly, but great will, vigour and eadine≈øse is in all men to perform the ≈øervice: We have about 7000 foot (with the Inhabitants) fighting men, and about 500 hor≈øe to face the enemy: Our provi≈øions con≈øume very fast, and every thing is exce≈ø≈øive dear, having now neither fi≈øh nor fle≈øh to come to our Markets, the enemy being po≈øse≈øsed of that which ≈øhould relieve us; and are in a pro≈øperous condition at pre≈øent, and like to do what they plea≈øe if our friends in England do not relieve us ≈øuddenly, and mocey to pay them and tho≈øe that are already here, and more provi≈øions for them all, for Wheat is here at 5. li. 10. s. the quarter, Rye at 4. li. 10. s. the quarter, little to ≈øell, and little money to buy it, our Men of War are come from Bewmorris, and divers ≈øhips from Che≈øter, and no men nor money, it is impo≈ø≈øible (in mans judgment) for us to hold out till ayd comes from England.

We have lost the good Town of Kildare, but it co≈øt the enemy very deer; for after three or four de≈øperate a≈ø≈øaults made by them on the breaches, made by their Canon, having lost many of their men they ≈øent for a parley, and ob≈øerving the undauted re≈øolution of Lies Col. Hute≈øon and Cap. Dixon, who commanded the men there, & mo- of the men vnder them, although many of their men would not figh≈øt at all, & are ≈øince gone to the enemy, that they gave our men quartet in two dayes to carry away what they had, where was great ≈øtore of corr and meal, Balle≈øoman is be≈øieged, and it must be lo≈øt becau≈øe we cannot come to relieve them.

We hear that Owen Oneal with his forces is joyned with them of Kilkenny against us, but we have no certainty thereof. We are in a very ≈øad condition, all our provi≈øions being almo≈øt all ≈øpent, yet I hope the Lord will defend this place, and that every one that puts his tru≈øt in him ≈øhall be delivered, to who≈øe ble≈ø≈øed protection I commend you, and re≈øt ever,

closer.signed: Your indeared, and mo≈øt affectionate friend, SAMUELL COTTON.

div.head: The Propo≈øitions of Generall Owen Oneal, the Lords, Gentry, and Commons of the Confederate Catholiques in Ul≈øter.
To the mo≈øt honorable and potent the Parliament of England.
div.p: IMprimis, That all Laws, Statutes, Penalties, made, pa≈øt, or concluded again≈øt the Roman Catholiques, its Mini≈øters or profe≈ø≈øors, their liberties and exerci≈øes of the ≈øaid Religion, ≈øince the 21 year of H. 8 to be reclaimed and perpetually to be taken off, and to extend to that party and their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors for ever.

2 That the ≈øaid Gen. Oneal de≈øires that an Act of Oblivion be pa≈ø≈øed to extend to all and every of his party, for all things done ≈øince the beginning of the year 1641. 3 They de≈øire that General Oneal be provided for a competent command in the army, befitting his place worth or quality. 4 That on both ≈øides, all jealou≈øies, hate and aver≈øion be laid a≈øide, unity, love and amity be renewed and proclaimed between both parties. 5 That the Army belonging to Generall Oneal and his party, be provided for in all points as the re≈øt of the Army ≈øhall be.

Letters further from Berwick ≈øay, That the Scots begin to unite and that the major part are for an agreement with their King; but (≈øay ≈øome) their chief object (at pre≈øent) is upon Dublin, and that if Generall Ormond becomes ma≈øter thereof, they intend a conjunction, and ≈øo to march into England with a very con≈øiderable Body, and the young King in the head of them. But the≈øe vapours are ≈øuppo≈øed to ari≈øe only from a Scotti≈øh Mi≈øt, which with one ≈øtrong Southernly Engli≈øh Gale, become quite expelled and di≈ø≈øolved.
